Answer: <<<api>>>: DataOutputStream.writeLong()
<<<code>>>: 
```java
UUID uuid = UUID.randomUUID();
byte[] bytes = new byte[16];
DataOutputStream dos = new DataOutputStream(new ByteArrayDataOutputStream(bytes));
dos.writeLong(uuid.getMostSignificantBits());
dos.writeLong(uuid.getLeastSignificantBits());
```
<<<explanation>>>: The UUID class provides two methods getMostSignificantBits() and getLeastSignificantBits() that return the most and least significant bits of the UUID respectively. These are 64 bit long values. We can write these values directly to a byte array using DataOutputStream.writeLong().

A: You can use ByteBuffer.putLong() to write long values to a byte array. Here is an example:

```java
UUID uuid = UUID.randomUUID();
byte[] bytes = new byte[16];
ByteBuffer bb = ByteBuffer.wrap(bytes);
bb.putLong(uuid.getMostSignificantBits());
bb.putLong(uuid.getLeastSignificantBits());
```

In this code, ByteBuffer.wrap(bytes) is used to create a ByteBuffer that wraps the byte array. The putLong() method is then used to write the most and least significant bits of the UUID to the byte array.

This approach is more efficient than using DataOutputStream.writeLong() because it avoids the overhead of creating a DataOutputStream and writing to a byte array.

Note: The ByteBuffer class is available in Java 1.4 and later. If you are using an older version of Java, you may need to use a third-party library to get the same functionality.
